reference.shortdesc: A required-cleanup element is used as a placeholder for migrated elements that cannot be appropriately tagged without manual intervention.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: As the element name implies, the intent for authors is to clean up the contained material and eventually remove the required-cleanup element. Authors should not insert this element into documents.

section.title: Processing expectations
section.p: Processors must strip this element from output by default. The content of required-cleanup is not considered to be verified data.
Processor options might be provided to allow a draft view of migrated content in context.

section.title: Attributes
section.p:
The following attributes are available on this element: (with a modified definition of translate, given below), and the attributes defined below.
remap Provides information about the origins of the content of the required-cleanup element. This provides authors context for determining how the migrated content should be tagged.
translate Indicates whether the content of the element should be translated or not. The default value for this element is "no"; setting to "yes" will override the default. The -dita-use-conref-target value is also available. The DITA architectural specification contains a list of each OASIS DITA element and its common processing default for the translate value; because this element uses an actual default, it will always be treated as translate="no" unless overridden as described.

example.title: Example
example.p: Presuming an original HTML document had contained some content within a center tag (for which there is no clear migrational equivalent in DITA), the following might be the result that is valid within an XML editor, but which requires an author to decide how to better tag or revise this original content:
example.codeblock: <section> <title>Some section title</title> <required-cleanup remap="center">Some original content migrated from a <center> tag.</required-cleanup> </section>
